duck: Resource (economics), commodity, service, or other asset used in production of goods and services, including
resource definition: a source of supply or support.
Resource - A resource is a source or supply from which benefit is produced.
Resource (computer science), physical or virtual entities of limited availability (e.g., memory, processing capacity, and network speed), including
Resource (project management), economic resources used in planning of tasks
Natural resource, anything obtained from the environment to satisfy human needs and wants
Resource (Macintosh), data associated with a Mac OS file
Computational resource, resource used for solving a computational problem
Water resources, sources of water that are useful or potentially useful
Resource (Windows), data embedded in EXE and DLL files
Human resources (HR), skills, energies, talents, abilities, and knowledge used for production
Resource (Web), anything identified by a Uniform Resource Identifier which can be found in a certain location
Resource (biology), substances or objects required by a biological organism for normal maintenance, growth, and reproduction

wiki.text:
A 'resource' is a source or supply from which benefit is produced. Typically
resources are materials, money, services, staff, or other assets that are
transformed to produce benefit and in the process may be consumed or made
unavailable. Benefits of resource utilization may include increased wealth,
meeting needs or wants, proper functioning of a system, or enhanced well being.
From a human perspective a natural resource is anything obtained from the
environment to satisfy human needs and wants.<ref name="autogenerated1">Miller,
G.T., and S. Spoolman. 2011. Living in the Environment: Principles, Connections,
and Solutions, 17th ed. Brooks-Cole, Belmont, CA. ISBN 0-538-73534-1.</ref> From
a broader biological or ecological perspective a resource satisfies the needs of
a living organism (see biological resource).<ref>Ricklefs, R.E. 2005. The
Economy of Nature, 6th ed. WH Freeman, New York, NY. ISBN 0-7167-8697-4.</ref>

The concept of resources has been applied in diverse realms, including with
respect to economics, biology, computer science, land management, and human
resources, and is linked to the concepts of competition, sustainability,
conservation, and stewardship. In application within human society, commercial
or non-commercial factors require resource allocation through resource
management.

Resources have three main characteristics: utility, limited availability, and
potential for depletion or consumption. Resources have been variously
categorized as biotic versus abiotic, renewable versus non-renewable, and
potential versus actual, along with more elaborate classifications.
wiki.title: resource
